item.title: ArgumentNullException / Don't forget the precedent!
item.description: At work this week, I discovered a quirk in the .NET API. An ArgumentException is thrown when one of the arguments to a method is invalid. A more specific ArgumentException is an ArgumentNullException which (as you may have guessed) is thrown when an argument is invalid because it is null. The funny thing is that while the base class provides this constructor - public ArgumentException (string message, string paramName); the one provided by the derived class is -
